block.p: Sudan Sending Arms Into Darfur, U.N. Says A confidential United Nations report says the government of Sudan is flying weapons and military equipment into Darfur in violation of Security Council resolutions and disguising military planes as United Nations or African Union aircraft.

Iran Weapons Linked to Taliban A shipment of Iranian-made weapons bound for the Taliban was recently captured by allied forces in Afghanistan, said Gen. Peter Pace, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He said it was not clear if the Iranian government had authorized the shipment.

Mixed News on AIDS Drugs About two million people worldwide are receiving drugs for AIDS, an increase of 700,000 in the last year, the United Nations reported. But the total represents only 28 percent of the people with advanced AIDS who need such therapy in poor and middle-income countries.

Calls for a Resignation in Basra In the latest sign of worsening tensions among Shiite factions, several hundred people began a protest to force the governor of Basra, Iraq, to step down, a move that could throw the city into further turmoil.

Confusion in Nigeria Election Election officials in Nigeria said a leading opposition candidate for president would appear on the ballot, even though a court ruling reversing his exclusion came just days before the vote. The Nigerian Supreme Court ruling threw an already chaotic election into further confusion.

Police Have Identified Virginia Tech Gunman The police identified Cho Seung-Hui, 23, as the killer of 32 people in the shooting rampage at the Virginia Polytechnic Institute, releasing new details into the troubled mind of a student whom few people on campus really knew.

Mr. Cho's gun purchase is drawing attention to Virginia's gun purchase laws, which some gun-control advocates described as lax, and it has prompted calls from several Democrats and at least one leading presidential candidate, John Edwards, for measures to restrict gun sales.

Student Database Is Restricted The Education Department cut off outside access to a government database that contains the personal financial information of millions of student aid applicants. The department acted after increased usage raised concerns that loan companies or other marketers were improperly obtaining private information on potential borrowers.

Coast Guard Seizes Control After months of criticism and setbacks, the Coast Guard announced that it was taking over the management of its $24 billion fleet modernization project, curtailing the role of two military contractors that had been hired to run the job.
F.D.A. Approves Flu Vaccine The first vaccine against avian flu won government approval, even as officials conceded its usefulness in a flu pandemic might be limited.

Corzine's Car Was Going 91 M.P.H., Data Shows A crash data recorder retrieved from the Chevrolet Suburban that was carrying Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey on the Garden State Parkway shows that it was traveling 91 miles per hour, 26 miles over the posted speed limit, when it collided with a truck and then slammed into a guardrail, leaving the governor critically injured. A1

Hard Times at Trailer Park The last remaining trailer park in Nassau County, which sits amid $1 million homes in the middle of Long Island's Gold Coast, has been sold to new owners, who plan to replace the park with luxury housing. B1

Storm's Upheaval Persists Residents in the New York region spent the day taking stock and mopping up from the rainiest April storm on record. More than 900 residents of Bound Brook, N.J., were still staying in shelters, and about 3,000 people were still without electricity, said acting Gov. Richard J. Codey. B1

Future of a Firm in Nigeria For years, Andrew Young, the civil rights leader, has been deeply involved in Nigeria through the lobbying and consulting firm he heads, GoodWorks International. But the question of what exactly GoodWorks is doing has turned Mr. Young and his firm into a lightning rod, as Nigerians prepare to elect a successor to the country's president, whom Mr. Young has known for 30 years. A1
